definition:
A [*Pythagorean prime*]{} $p$ is a prime number of the form $4n + 1$.
The first few are 5, 13, 17, 29, 37, 41, 53, 61, 73, 89, 97, etc.,
listed in A002144 of Sloane’s OEIS. Because of its form, a Pythagorean
prime is the sum of two squares, e.g., 29 = 25 + 4. In fact, with the
exception of 2, these are the only primes that can be represented as the
sum of two squares (thus, in Waring’s problem, all other primes require
three or four squares).

Though Pythagorean primes are primes on the line of real integers, they
are not Gaussian primes in the complex plane. Expressing a Pythagorean
prime as $a^2 + b^2$ (it doesn’t matter whether $a < b$ or viceversa)
leads to the complex factorization by simple plugging in of the values
thus: $p = (a + bi)(a - bi)$, where $i$ is the imaginary unit.
